function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Increased risk of zoonotic tick-borne infections due to climate change-induced increase in tick population and expansion of their habitats.","Impact":"Higher incidence of tick-borne infections in humans and pets, and spread of infections to new areas.","Mitigation":"Reducing the population of ticks and their transmission pathways, as well as implementing preventive measures for humans and pets.","Technologies":"Tick control measures, habitat management, and public health interventions.","People":"Residents, outdoor workers, and pet owners in urban green environments.","Owner":"Public health organizations, local government, and community organizations."},{"Description":"Conflicting impact of deer density on tick-borne infections, with some studies suggesting a reduction and others indicating an increase in infections.","Impact":"Uncertainty in the relationship between deer density and tick-borne infections, leading to challenges in disease prevention and management.","Mitigation":"Further research to understand the complex interactions between deer, ticks, and tick-borne pathogens, and development of targeted interventions based on the findings.","Technologies":"Research technologies for ecological studies, surveillance tools for tick-borne diseases, and advanced modeling techniques.","People":"Researchers, wildlife management agencies, and public health authorities.","Owner":"Scientific institutions, government agencies, and interdisciplinary research teams."},{"Description":"Dependency of other tick-borne diseases on the presence of deer, leading to increased risk of transmission and spread.","Impact":"Elevated likelihood of transmission and spread of tick-borne diseases such as Babesia spp. and Anaplasma due to the presence of cervides.","Mitigation":"Implementing strategies to manage the population and distribution of cervides, as well as developing targeted interventions for controlling diseases dependent on deer.","Technologies":"Wildlife management techniques, disease surveillance and control tools, and ecological modeling for disease transmission dynamics.","People":"Wildlife conservationists, public health officials, and local communities near deer habitats.","Owner":"Wildlife management agencies, public health organizations, and local government bodies."}]}
